column1: #Text=New stars have been recently discovered in the Southern Cross , or Crux , by scientists in the United States .

#Text=This discovery could affect the flags of New Zealand , Australia , Papua New Guinea , Samoa and Brazil , although the new star is located very close to the westernmost star and invisible to the naked eye .

#Text=The American scientists found the new stars in the Southern Cross by using the Chandra X-ray Observatory , a space satellite run by NASA ( National Aeronautics and Space Administration ) which uses x-rays .

#Text=When the scientist team , led by David Cohen of Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania , were using the Chandra telescope , they , to their surprise , saw two x-ray glows , each representing stars , where they expected to see one .
#Text=The new star appears to be orbiting Beta Crucis , the westernmost star in the Southern Cross , once every 2,000 years .

#Text=Doctor Nick Lomb , an astronomer at the Powerhouse Museum , Sydney , Australia , said that the reason the star had not been found before was because the glare from Beta Crucis is too great and " It would be like looking for a glow worm next to a floodlight . "
#Text=Before the recent discovery , it was already known that Beta Crucis had a partner , which is invisible to the human-eye .
#Text=Mr Cohen said that they found it by accident , as they were really trying to get information about the x-rays emitted by Beta Crucis . "

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=We were interested in how the highly supersonic stellar winds of hot , luminous stars produce X-rays .

_	_	_	_

#Text=The star found at the bottom of the Southern Cross , Alpha Crucis  Acrux " , also has a partner star , which is also invisible to the human-eye .

column1: #Text=This invisible partner is not featured on any flags .

#Text=Dr Lomb said the apparent separation between each star is like looking at two headlights from 100 kilometres away , even though the two stars are actually 60 billion kilometres away from each other .
#Text=Dr Lomb said that if Australia was to put all eight stars in the Southern Cross onto the Australia flag then " the flag would have to be huge , probably the size of Sydney . "

#Text=Astronomer Alan Gilmore from University of Canterbury 's Mount John observatory , also agreed that flags should not be altered because it is not about how many stars there are in the Southern Cross , but the magnitude of the stars .
#Text=Mr Gilmore said : " What you see by eye is what you see on the flag .
